channel.title: Released Engine
channel.description:
Hey there, I'm releasing an old revision of my engine (the revision that had gouraud shading)
[img]http://i58.tinypic.com/2w2ik1w.png[/img]
Contains source and an info.txt telling you some extra information as well as the following...
[font=helvetica]Includes:[/font]
[font=helvetica]Triangle rasterization[/font] [font=helvetica]Gouraud shading model[/font] [font=helvetica]Z-Buffering[/font] [font=helvetica]First person camera[/font]
[font=helvetica]WASD - Walk[/font] [font=helvetica]Arrow Keys - Look[/font] [font=helvetica]T / G - move up / down[/font] [font=helvetica]Esc - quit program[/font]
[font=helvetica]Features removed:[/font]
[font=helvetica]Texture mapping[/font] [font=helvetica]Custom font rendering[/font]
[font=helvetica][url=http://www.mediafire.com/download/fa4ggk3mhkrbw51/RasterizerByArchive.zip]http://www.mediafire.com/download/fa4ggk3mhkrbw51/RasterizerByArchive.zip[/url][/font]
https://github.com/Turbo-Limits/RArchive/tree/master

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:51, topic:551811”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=670727.msg4488091#msg4488091 date=1435601766]

I noticed in your Matrix class you are declaring strictfp. Is there any particular reason for this? Seems strange to see in a high-demanding games math library.

Just to make sure the fixed point -> floating point conversion is consistent. (At least that’s what I think strictfp does, it doesnt hurt putting the modifier there lol)

@my-swagger: Thank you, I have a bad habit of trying to write as little code as possible to get the desired effect. Too many methods, etc, tend to confuse me. I’m still working on that haha :p.
I learned some important things from David Brackeen’s Developing Games In Java and also this great finnish owned website from the 90s called 3DICA. My dad helped me with the matrix math, and of course there were some misc websites that helped solidify my learning.
[/quote]http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5181256/strictfp-in-java

I can’t think of a situation where strictfp is useful for games. Portability doesn’t matter and it comes at a cost. Spending extra cycles in the FPU is a waste for games, especially since you can’t see a visual difference when it comes down to actually interacting with the environment you’re rendering. This is why games choose to use floats instead of doubles. Wouldn’t double the precision be better? It turns out to pretty much never matter. If you are keeping your floating point values within the highest area of precision the float can offer (between -1 and 1), then you don’t really need anymore precision than that. (To be fair, Intel processors are a bit weird with this and often extend 32-bit floats to something like 80-bit floats, so precision literally doesn’t matter for performance in this case, but that’s not consistent across architectures).[/quote]
Strictfp doesn’t affect performance afaik

Read full topic

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:20, topic:551811”][quote author=Limits link=topic=670727.msg4488048#msg4488048 date=1435562196]

I noticed in your Matrix class you are declaring strictfp. Is there any particular reason for this? Seems strange to see in a high-demanding games math library.

Just to make sure the fixed point -> floating point conversion is consistent. (At least that’s what I think strictfp does, it doesnt hurt putting the modifier there lol)

@my-swagger: Thank you, I have a bad habit of trying to write as little code as possible to get the desired effect. Too many methods, etc, tend to confuse me. I’m still working on that haha :p.
I learned some important things from David Brackeen’s Developing Games In Java and also this great finnish owned website from the 90s called 3DICA. My dad helped me with the matrix math, and of course there were some misc websites that helped solidify my learning.
[/quote]http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5181256/strictfp-in-java[/quote]

I can’t think of a situation where strictfp is useful for games. Portability doesn’t matter and it comes at a cost. Spending extra cycles in the FPU is a waste for games, especially since you can’t see a visual difference when it comes down to actually interacting with the environment you’re rendering. This is why games choose to use floats instead of doubles. Wouldn’t double the precision be better? It turns out to pretty much never matter. If you are keeping your floating point values within the highest area of precision the float can offer (between -1 and 1), then you don’t really need anymore precision than that. (To be fair, Intel processors are a bit weird with this and often extend 32-bit floats to something like 80-bit floats, so precision literally doesn’t matter for performance in this case, but that’s not consistent across architectures).

Read full topic

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

Read:

Design Patterns
Just take a read of the wiki entry to get a rough idea.

en.wikipedia.org

Software design pattern

In software engineering, a software design pattern is a general, reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem within a given context in software design. It is not a finished design that can be transformed directly into source or machine code. It is a description or template for how to solve a problem that can be used in many different situations. Design patterns are formalized best practices that the programmer can use to solve common problems when designing an application or system. Object-...

High cohesion, low coupling
This is something you seem to struggle with a fair bit. Read the below two links for an explanation.

The Bojan's Blog – 8 Apr 15

High Cohesion, Loose Coupling

We are living in a time where businesses and the people running them often change their mind. I won’t be going into details of why is that so, let’s just say it is a given, and let̵…


stackoverflow.com

What does 'low in coupling and high in cohesion' mean

oop, ooad
asked by user1315906 on 06:57AM - 22 Dec 12

Ebooks:

Head First Design Patterns:
"At any given moment, someone struggles with the same software design problems you have. And, chances are, someone else has already solved your problem. This edition of Head First Design Patterns—now updated for Java 8—shows you the tried-and-true, road-tested patterns used by developers to create functional, elegant, reusable, and flexible software. By the time you finish this book, you’ll be able to take advantage of the best design practices and experiences of those who have fought the beast of software design and triumphed."
LINK: http://shop.oreilly.com/product/9780596007126.do

[i]Code Complete (2nd Edition) (Developer Best Practices)
"Widely considered one of the best practical guides to programming, Steve McConnell’s original CODE COMPLETE has been helping developers write better software for more than a decade. Now this classic book has been fully updated and revised with leading-edge practices—and hundreds of new code samples—illustrating the art and science of software construction. Capturing the body of knowledge available from research, academia, and everyday commercial practice, McConnell synthesizes the most effective techniques and must-know principles into clear, pragmatic guidance. No matter what your experience level, development environment, or project size, this book will inform and stimulate your thinking—and help you build the highest quality code. "
LINK: http://www.amazon.com/Code-Complete-Edition-Developer-Practices-ebook/dp/B00JDMPOSY

The Pragmatic Programmer: From Journeyman to Master
"Straight from the programming trenches, The Pragmatic Programmer cuts through the increasing specialization and technicalities of modern software development to examine the core process–taking a requirement and producing working, maintainable code that delights its users. It covers topics ranging from personal responsibility and career development to architectural techniques for keeping your code flexible and easy to adapt and reuse"
LINK: http://www.amazon.com/The-Pragmatic-Programmer-Journeyman-Master-ebook/dp/B003GCTQAE/ref=pd_sim_351_1?ie=UTF8&refRID=0XCC5H0G18ATQ601F0ZF

Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship
"Even bad code can function. But if code isn’t clean, it can bring a development organization to its knees. Every year, countless hours and significant resources are lost because of poorly written code. But it doesn’t have to be that way."
LINK: http://www.amazon.com/Clean-Code-Handbook-Software-Craftsmanship-ebook/dp/B001GSTOAM/ref=pd_sim_351_2?ie=UTF8&refRID=0XCC5H0G18ATQ601F0ZF

Read full topic

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Ok, Ill try to do an example as close to your code as possible.

Let’s take a different type of concrete object, like a polygon.

public class Polygon {
  private Point[] verts;
}

Now, if we are going to create methods for this object, we want to make sure they fit the class’ definition and don’t extend outside the scope of what this class is for. What is the class definition? To represent a polygon and provide methods to manipulate it. Note that when I say scope it’s not a language definition that can actually result in errors or anything, I mean scope as in the scope of the class theoretical perceived definition.

Here’s an example of a manipulation method:

public class Polygon {
  private Point[] verts;

  public void translate(int tX, int tY) {
    for(Point p : verts) {
      p.translate(tX, tY);
    }
  }
}

Here’s an example of an out of scope manipulation method (what you have):

public class Polygon {
  private Point[] verts;

  public void translateBasedOnSomethingUnrelatedToThePolygon() {
    for(Point p : verts) {
      p.translate(MyRandomStaticClass.translateX, MyRandomStaticClass.translateY);
    }
  }
}

To achieve the same result, you’d have the correct translate method and you’d call [tt]translate(MyRandomStaticClass.translateX, MyRandomStaticClass.translateY)[/tt] instead.

Alternatively in some cases if you are using a more ‘custom’ object (a polygon is a concrete mathematical object), you can pass around your other custom objects (cough camera instance), like [tt]translate(myCustomClassInstance)[/tt]

and have methods like

public class MyCustomObjectThatHasPoints {
  private Point[] verts;

  public void translate(MyCustomClass c) {
    for(Point p : verts) {
      p.translate(c.translateX, c.translateY);
    }
  }
}

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Davidi2:

just remember. an object shouldnt be using things outside of its scope. its ok to have the camera class be static if you want, but even in that case you should be passing the static reference around to the methods that need to use it rather than having objects call the static one all the time. makes it a nightmare if you ever decide to NOT make it static

Can you give me an example? im having a hard time understanding what you’re trying to explain to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:37, topic:551811”][quote author=Limits link=topic=670727.msg4488151#msg4488151 date=1435613932]
@Davidi2: I use a vector for the 3D location of the camera, the rotations are stored in int vars
[/quote]its just bad practice to have an object like that perform operations on itself based on some static object somewhere. a vector class should have functionality related to vectors, not cameras. you would instead have that interpret() method somewhere else and you’d call operations on the vector from outside it to change it. same logic behind not having that static DEPTH_OF_FIELD value in there, you’d have that somewhere else and use it when calling operations on the vector

im not 100% sure because im not a mathematician, but I dont think its called interpreting the vector, its like translating or transforming or something[/quote]
Yeah i was considering calling the method “transform” at first but the word seemed to vague and the word interpret seemed like it fit. I have two static classes in this project I believe… Surface and Camera, i didnt make them real classes because there is only one instance and all they do is manipulate some numbers

And ok i’ll rework the whole vector issue.

Read full topic

item.title: Released Engine
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

JOGE:

Limits: Hey man I saw ur JOGE engine and I was wondering if I could use it in my project. Also how do I go about using one of these, as I've never used a game engine before. Do I need to read and understand all the methods in the JOGE source files?
object: Hello there! Sure you can. :) It doesn't have a lot of documentation, but I guess that's one way you can learn about it. On the other hand, the source code for the Ludum Dare game I made with JOGE, is also open source. It hasn't been uploaded to GitHub just yet. But you can find it on my project page, on the following link: http://martus.se/ld29/surface_invaders/. There should be a link to a ZIP file with the source code.
Limits: Thanks! And I'm mostly going to use JOGE to help me understand how a 3D engine works and hopefully I can eventually make my own. There aren't many good examples like yours, thanks again!
Limits: Do you know how I can get started on writing my own real 3D game engine like yours?
object: Yes, I do. Do like me, buy the book Developing Games in Java by David Brackeen. You can find his site at http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/. My game engine is inspired by his work, to some extent. I even use modified code from his examples.
Limits: Sounds cool, this book explains 3D and everything? I don't want pseudo-3D i want real 3D, like your engine. I'm very interested in learning how a game and it's engine works and I want to write one for my already existing 2D game to make it 3D.
object: Yes, that book is probably the best I have read, when it comes to showing how to implement 3D games in Java. It shows how to build your own software rasterizer, BSP trees, collision detection, AI (even self-learning ones) and a bunch more. No hardware accelerated graphics are covered. But it does cover what you need, from 2D to 3D and the basics as well as more advanced things, like shading. It does not cover how to build your own particle system, however. But you can always take a look at my implementation as a reference. My engine is based on it, as I said. Well, I did write everything on my own from scratch. But I have used that book as a reference for a lot of things.
Limits: I got the book and I have to say, it is very detailed and informative but I feel as though I'm not at that level in math or computer science in general. I'm 15 years old taking AP Computer Science starting this september and I'm going into pre-calculus. I simply cannot understand the terms and equations used to do all of this. Thank you however, I will definitely use this book in the future.
object: I suck at math too! ;) I barely knew what a vector was when I started with 3D programming. But that book has helped quite a lot. Well, I do have a few other books as well. Probably around 10 or so. But all the others are much harder to grasp, as they are all very theoretical. I know practically nothing when it comes to math notations. If I see an algorithm in code, that's a whole different story, however. I'm more pattern-oriented than math-oriented. But I guess math could be translated into patterns easily, as they're practically the same thing. Although I never figured that out. First I have to decipher the semantics of all used math notations. :)
Question:

Limits: Hey I was wondering how I could get a 2D sprite in my 3D world, you know, as a NPC and stuff.
object: Well, the only thing I have used is polygons with transparent textures. Not really sprites then I guess. But it works somewhat.
Limits: Sounds good
Limits: How do you get transparent textures to be color indexed? GIMP doesnt seem to be able to do it.
object: The code in the book does not even support transparency, though. I had to fix that on my own first. But in GIMP you have this Magic Wand tool (I think that's the name of it). Just select the part you wish to make transparent and delete it. Or you can add a new alpha channel to the image from some of the menus (maybe the Layer menu, if that is the name of it).
Limits: How do I make it support transparency? Is it hard? And GIMP works for everything that doesnt have a transparent pixel in it.
object: I don't remember exactly what I had to change. It really wasn't that hard, though. By the way, why don't you figure things out on your own? Remember, you don't like crediting people. So, the best way for you to stick to that, is to think on your own. Or, consult Wikipedia and Google if you're really clueless about something.
Limits: Ok. and yeah I'd love to figure things out on my own if I knew where to start..
Limits: Hey, I've been working on this issue for the past two days for at least 12 hours each day. I read more in Brackeen's Java book and read that he uses "Index Transparency" I googled it but I couldn't find anything that allows me to do it in GIMP or anything. If you know could you please explain? Thank you so much, I feel bad for bothering you so much but I just don't know much about graphics.
object: I don't remember if I support transparency on shaded textures. But I do on normal textures (PowerOf2Texture). I changed it from RGB to ARGB (BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB). Then I updated all places where the RGB value was used, such that ARGB is used instead.
Limits: That would be terrific if Brackeen didn't use BufferedImage.TYPE_USHORT_565_RGB instead of TYPE_INT_(A)RGB for non shaded textures.
another question :P:

Limits: Hey, I read on your post about your game engine that it can load maps via xml? Do you have a sample .xml map?
object: Hey! Yes, it can load maps via XML. But it's not really that good. And, it shouldn't be that hard for you to figure out the format, by reading the code. No, I don't have an example file to give away.
Limits: Okay, thanks! I'm just trying to learn how XML works. Is it efficient?
object: XML is just a markup-language. So I cannot say it's neither efficient nor inefficient. If anything, it's quite verbose and takes up more space than other markup-languages, such as JSON, which probably means it will take longer to parse. But that shouldn't be of any concern to you. On the other hand, it's very similar to HTML, if you have ever used that? In fact, XHTML is actually based on XML, hence the X in the name.
Limits: Oh cool thanks! I'm just wondering if loading things off of a text file using my own 'syntax' instead of Xml is a better idea
object: That's entirely up to you to decide. If you decide to create your own format, you can create a less verbose one. Which of course is good. It's extremely easy to do, though, so go for it.
Limits: Ok thanks man

Read full topic
